metadata.title: Quick Algorithm Lookup 101. Looking at some of the other common… | by Paul May | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: If you think of Data Science your mind will often drift towards Neural Networks, but there are actually a wealth of other algorithms that a data scientists will have in mind with their own strengths…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I have an article here on it in more depth if you are interested

all_paragraphs: If you think of Data Science your mind will often drift towards Neural Networks, but there are actually a wealth of other algorithms that a data scientists will have in mind with their own strengths or weaknesses.

Of course, these offer a selection of some of the more commonly used ones and in many cases, there are more complicated versions which address issues or add increased capability. However, to keep this article short I’ve only included the more basic versions.
I won’t be covering Neural Networks because there are hundreds of articles about them, but if you do want a quick introduction I can recommend my quick introduction article.
Before we start it is good for me to go over several terms I’ll be using in brackets under their titles and what I mean when I use them:

N.B. When talk about labelled data, it is meant that we know the result (i.e. that a picture is of a “dog” or a “cat”) and is that result that we are trying to get the Machine Learning algorithm to replicate. For unsupervised the equivalent would be that it looks for groupings and distinctions in the data but it does not know the answer (i.e. it groups all pictures into different animal types but it doesn’t know that one group is a “cat” and another “snake”).
(Supervised Learning, White Box Method, Regression Method)

Used to estimate real values based on a continuous variable. It establishes a relationship between the independent and dependent variables by fitting a line of best fit to the data points. This “best fit” line is known as a regression line and is represented (for one independent variable) as:
If multiple independent variables are to be used then Multiple Linear Regression would be used. It is also possible to fit polynomial and curvilinear lines as well.
To fit the regression line different strategies can be used but the most common are:
Authors Note: Both Singular and Multiple Linear Regression is possible in Excel if you are limited on tools
(Supervised Learning, White Box Method, Classification Method)

The classification version of Linear regression. This takes discrete (e.g. “yes” or “no”) rather than continuous variables (e.g. 0.0 to 1.0). It makes a probabilistic assessment of if it belongs in a class by fitting a Logistic Function (also known as a Logit Function) to the independent variables. Therefore the outputs will be between 0.0 and 1.0, which can be interpreted as a probability.
For a quick example of how it works we will use a two classification problem (“event occurred” and “event did not occur”) and one independent variable, x, then the Logit function, σ, will look like:
If we assume that, y, comes from a linear combination of independent variables then for this case it will look like:
Therefore the Logit function will change to:

F(x) can be interpreted as the probability of the event occurring in this case. Usually a threshold cut-off is then utilised to determine at what probability level the event is classified as “having occurred”, one method is to use an ROC curve and a confusion matrix to optimise.

This example is one of Binary Logistic Regression where only two classifications are available, however, many other forms exist that can perform many more classifications (Multinomial Logistic Regression) and are also capable of taking more input variables. Forms also exist that care whether the classifications are ordinal or not.
Author Note: It is possible to perform a Binary Logistic Regression in Excel (with one or more independent variables). However, expect it to be hard work to debug!
(Supervised Learning, White Box Method, Classification Method, Regression Method)

This algorithm works by selecting the input variable that can best split the data (with minimal wrong choices compared to the other input variables) and then splits the data based on a rule (e.g. “If the time is greater than 5 hours”). It then takes each set of split data in turn and then finds the next variable (or uses the same one again) to split the data again. It keeps doing this until a “tree” of decisions are made that result in an output of homogeneous sets of data that are all the same label. A flowchart of the decisions is capable of being produced and studied by the Data Scientist. This makes it useful for interpreting the results but also for embedding within devices not capable of housing a machine learning algorithm as is.

To summarise, the algorithm continuously splits the data into 2 or more homogeneous datasets based on the most significant input variables to make as many distinct groups as possible. This splitting can be done by various measures, such as:

But how does it decide a split is any good using one of these measures you ask? Well commonly the split is measured by a change in a metric. Commonly this might be by impurity, where the purity of the split samples combined is much smaller than the non-split data and the split that reduces the purity the most is chosen. I have an article here on it in more depth if you are interested.
This algorithm is capable of performing regression and classification analyses.

Author Note: This algorithm (along with Decision Forests) tends to be one of the most commonly used algorithms a Data Scientist will use due to its flexibility and the ability to study how decisions are reached. It often gives a surprisingly good result which can serve as a benchmark for later algorithms.
(Supervised Learning, Black Box Method, Classification Method, Regression Method)

Following directly on from Decision Trees it is worth mentioning Random Forests. In the simplest terms Random Forests are simply a collection of Decision Trees, where each tree makes it’s own decision given the data and then perform a collective vote. The winning decision is then given as the output. Just like a Decision Tree it is capable of making both regression and classifications.
The basic method of “planting” and “growing” a forest is1 by “tree bagging”:

The results of this method is that not every tree will see the same input data and input variables which results in a reduction in the chances of over-fitting, but also improved model performance. The disadvantages is that many trees (100s to 1000s or more) are often required and takes a large computation time as a result. One advantage is that the optimal number of trees can be found by looking at the “out-of-bag-error”. This is where for each tree is it is given the input data that was not part of the original random sample that was used to create it. The result performance of each tree is then aggregated and by looking at the error against the number of trees “planted” there will often be a plateau where no further model improvement is gained by adding more trees.

Author Note: Work has been put in the last few years to increase the interpretability of Random Forests. These include, feature importance and decision paths (looking at average responses per feature).
(Supervised Learning, Black Box Method, Classification Method, Regression Method)

This algorithm is traditionally used for classification problems, but is capable of regression as well (with growing usage in such areas). The aim of the algorithm is to insert a flat boundary that separates the classes into their respective groups. In the most basic level if on a graph one class has points in the bottom left and the other class is in the top right the algorithm will insert a line that goes from the top left to the bottom right. This line is the “decision boundary” and the classification of new points is made by which side of the line the points land. For data that is not so easily separated, the SVM increases the dimensionality of the data (each feature is plotted as a co-ordinate) plotted until it can insert a flat hyper plane boundary that separates the classes.

The boundary is usually inserted so that it is maximises the distance (equidistant) between the closest points of each class from the line and the mathematics involved tend to create great difficulty in giving an interpretable result. The mapping of the data (which is what kernel functions essentially do) into higher dimensions uses a “kernel trick” which is a method where the boundary can be fitted without having to go through the full expensive computational cost of converting all the data to co-ordinates in a high order dimension. Additionally because only the data points that are close to the decision boundary (these points are called support vectors) are used in the decision of where to place the boundary the other points are not needed. This can give the SVM an advantage in being able to compactly store and train the model.
The SVM can be a very powerful tool that have been used in several different fields. Such as:
Authors Note: Versions of the SVM that can perform unsupervised learning are available and called “Support Vector Clustering”
Authors Note 2: To date some of the most powerful results from machine learning have been from SVM and Neural Networks (sometimes competing on similar challenges)
(Supervised Learning, White Box Method, Classification Method)
This model uses an assumption of independence between input variables and utilise Bayes Theorem to produce a way of classifying data.
The basic equation of Bayes Theorem is:

It has strong advantages in that it is interpretable, easy to build, quick to train and it can make decisions very quickly. This is useful for very large datasets and in certain industries (such as those trying to quantify risk). It has even been known to outperform much more complicated and sophisticated models and methods.
Author Note: Because this algorithm assumes independence of input variables, if they are not then this can strongly influence the resulting model.
(Supervised Learning, Black Box Method, Classification Method, Regression Method)
This is widely utilised to perform classifications, but regression problems are also possible.

The method that is used is one of grouping. By plotting the points in feature space and a new data point is added, the nearest, K, neighbours are found for it spatially. The classification is then just the most common amongst those nearest neighbours.

The distant measure doesn’t have to be purely Euclidean (Manhattan and Minkowski have also been used), but choosing the correct value for K can be one of the challenges with this model. Fortunately the models are very quick to train, but because they store all the data they can be large and to get a result can be computationally very expensive because it has to find the K nearest neighbours each time.

Authors Note: It is important that all input variables are normalised when using this model, otherwise the model will be more strongly influenced by certain variables over others purely by their value ranges.
(Unsupervised Learning, Box Method, Classification Method)
This is an example of an unsupervised machine learning algorithm. The basic methodology is:
Superficially this appears similar to KNN, but it works in a different manner. It does have the problem of determining the number of initial K points to place, but estimations of these can be made.

The method for helping to optimise the value K is for each cluster to sum the square differences for each cluster datapoint to the cluster centroid. When these values are summed we then have a cluster solution for each model. By changing the value of K and re-computing the cluster solution we can see that this value should decrease as the value of K increases, but there will be a point where the gain of increasing K is diminished. This provides a guide to the optimal value of K.
Author note: Well mixed data can be hard to separate. Consider two interlinked spirals, a standard K-Means will not be able separate the two. However, different methods exist to combat this.
I hope this list has been informative about how (at least at a high-level) some of the common data science algorithms work and also what some of their strengths and weaknesses are.
Of course with the field constantly learning and developing all the time this can never be an exhaustive list, but knowing these will help you understand others.
Data Scientist, Astrophysics PhD, reliability engineer and part time writer. I love exploring the world of science and how it shapes the world we live in.
